ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot more about close readings of texts written by Black authors.

This course taught me so muchnot only about literature by Black Southern authors, but about the radicalism of literature of the Black South and how fiction can create joy, revolution, grief, and pain. It is so, so powerful, and I am extraordinarily lucky to have received this exposure to it.
I learned how to follow themes across texts that are not at first glance related.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Wonderful books, and wonderful discussions. I always learned something new in every seminar.

I really enjoyed the readings in this course, and the workload was manageable. The final exam made it a little difficult to parse out time studying during finals alongside the paper, but was not too difficult to prep for.

Strengths: The books. They're pretty much all fantastic, and Professor Mahurin makes sure to bring you into her enthusiasm about every text. She is truly one of the most fantastic teachers I've ever hadI was glued to my seat for the entirety of each class, which is a big deal for me, since I often struggle with staying focused for more than 45 minutes. 

Weaknesses: Having an exam AND an essay at the end of the semester doesn't actually make as much sense as Professor Mahurin seems to think that it does. Her rationale is that people who are stronger on exams will have an opportunity to excel in the course, and the same being true for students who are better at essays. However, this logic would only really hold up if there were an option to pick one or the otherby having us all complete both, it's only making it harder for BOTH strong essay writers and strong test takers to excel. Additionally, the exam is essentially tests our essay-writing skills, so that sort of defeats the purpose. All of that being said, there weren't many other opportunities to receive academic feedback or to work on improving your grade outside of the midterm essay, the presentation, and the final exam and essay. I think Professor Mahurin should consider adding in some response papers or something and getting rid of the exam. Also, we essentially receive no guidance on either essay, so it would be helpful to have some sort of written outline of her expectations for these essays.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, this class really opens your eyes to a lot of things you may not see when you read these books. The books are also amazing as well, and there are few assignments so you really get to spend a lot more time enjoying the content of the class.
Yes; every reading we had was valuable and the class discussion was always interesting and in-depth. One of my favorite courses this semester.

This is the best class I've ever taken, at Yale or outside of it. I cannot recommend it highly enough. If you like to read and talk about those readings, take this class. TAKE THIS CLASS. If you can, it's tough to get into, but Professor Mahurin appreciates diligence so be persistent and try to get in a year or two before you plan on taking it so that you can say you've tried in the past.

Absolutely! One of the best courses I've taken at Yale. Dean Mahurin is such a wonderful, insightful, and empathetic educator. Every Yale student should have a class of hers on their Yale bucket list.
If an English major or from the South, I would recommend this course.

extras.title: AFAM 206 01/ENGL 234 01 - Literature of the Black South
